title: Past: Historical Ecosystems
text:
BpS models represent the vegetation system that may have been dominant on the landscape prior to Euro-American settlement. These models are based on a combination of the current environment and an approximation of the historical disturbance regime. Read more.

Check out this 3-minute tutorial for a quick refresher on the basics of Biophysical Settings Models.
Use this page as a starting point to explore the most prevalent BpSs on the Ouachita National Forest. In addition to the charts and maps, the historical disturbance data can be directly accessed using this site.

title: Past: Historical Ecosystems
text:
Summary

Historically, more than 80% of the Ouachita National Forest was covered by the Ozark-Ouachita Shortleaf Pine-Oak Forest and Woodland. Much of the composition of the woodlands and forests was a function of changes in slope and aspect, with more open, pine and dry oak communities occurring on dry, south facing slopes, and denser, more mesic, oak communities concentrated on wetter north facing slopes.
The Ozark-Ouachita Shortleaf-Pine Bluestem Woodland covered more than 25% of the area, a Biophysical Setting characterized by a shortleaf pine dominated canopy (Pinus echinata) and open understory dominated by big bluestem (Andropogon gerardii), little bluestem (Schizachium scoparium), and other sun loving plants species more often observed in prairie communities. Much of this setting occurred on the large, more gently sloping east/west ridges of the Ouachitas Mountains, on primarily sandstone and shale substrates.
More than 95% of the Ouachita National Forest had a Mean Fire Return Interval (MFRI) of 20 years or less, with roughly 40% having a MFRI of less than 5 years.
Surface fire was by far, the most prevalent historic disturbance.
Overall, more than 600,000 acres of surface fire burned throughout the Ouachita National Forest per year, with roughly 300,000 acres burning through the ‘Ozark-Ouachita Shortleaf Pine-Bluestem Woodland’ ecosystem. Native grazing was the second-most common disturbance, but was low in comparison to fire disturbance, affecting roughly 30,000 acres per year.

title: Comparisons
text:
Using LANDFIRE’s BpS products, we explore two different ways to visualize past vs. current vegetation patterns.

First, we present changes in broad ecosystem types using an interactive comparison diagram. To present these broad ecosystem trends more effectively, we combined classifications of Existing Vegetation Types (EVT) into broader categories. The Developed EVTs of high, medium, and low intensity, and Quarries-Strip Mines-Gravel Pits EVTs were combined into one “Developed” EVT. Exotic Herbaceous and Exotic Tree-shrub EVTs were combined into one “Exotics” EVT.
Second, we compare amounts of succession classes (past and present) for the most prevalent ecosystems.

title: Comparisons
text:
Comparing Broad Vegetation Trends

Summary
There has not been broad large-scale conversion of ecosystems from one type to another (see circular chord diagram below). However, some patterns are worth noting:

There has been a broad-scale change from ‘hardwood’ type to more ‘conifer’ types. Likely due primarily to conversion of hardwood to pine for timber production.
There has been some conversion from past conifer, past hardwood, past hardwood-conifer, and past grassland to developed and agricultural types, though overall, the forest remains heavily forested.
Acres of grassland have been dramatically reduced. Almost all of the past 30,000 acres of grassland have been converted to agriculture, exotic, and forested types.
Exotic types now represent roughly 55,000 acres of the forest.

Note: number presented when hovering equals acres.

title: Comparisons
section: Succession classes for three most dominant BpSs
text:
Succession classes for three most dominant BpSs
These three communities had some interesting shifts in succession classes (See chart below).

There was a increase in succession class E, in all three ecosystems. Succession class E is characterized as closed canopy (>71% canopy cover) with a sparse herbaceous understory. As fire has been identified as the most prevalent disturbance on this landscape, this shift is presumably due to lack of fire on the landscape.
The ‘Ozark-Ouachita Shortleaf Pine-Bluestem Woodland’ community had the most dramatic shift in succession class, with much of the past Succession Class D and C, described as mid to late-seral woodland savannah, with pine oak overstory and bluestem grass understory, shifting to closed canopy forest (Succession Class E).
All three ecosystems had dramatic reductions in Succession Classes A, B, and C. These succession classes are early and mid development classes, with seedling and sapling trees (Class A) to midstory trees (< 10m tree height) (Class B and C). Overall, this trend suggests that in the past, higher intensity and frequency of disturbance (primarily fire) shifted ecosystems into, and maintained, these earlier succession classes.

title: About this Project
text: This project is the result of a meaningful collaboration across The Nature Conservancy, serving as a demonstration of data products that may be created using LANDFIRE data. These charts, maps, and graphs are based on current LANDFIRE products, and provide a starting point for further analysis. All maps, input datasets and further assistance can be obtained by contacting TNC Ecologists (and authors of this assessment), Randy Swaty and Melanie Rudolf.

title: About this Project
text:
What is LANDFIRE?
LANDFIRE, Landscape Fire and Resource Management Planning Tools , is a shared program between the wildland fire management programs of the U.S. Department of Agriculture Forest Service Fire and Aviation branch, and the U.S. Department of the Interior, that provides more than twenty landscape-scale geo-spatial products, 950 vegetation models, and a suite of tools that support all-lands planning, management, and operations.

title: About this Project
section: What is The Nature Conservancy’s connection?
text:
What is The Nature Conservancy’s connection?
The Nature Conservancy (TNC) is a Major Partner in the LANDFIRE Program supported by a cooperative agreement. TNC’s LANDFIRE Team works closely with the LANDFIRE Business Leads, program staff, and other partners to provide user support through:

Helping users understand the strengths, weaknesses, and appropriate uses of LANDFIRE products
Locating, obtaining, and using geospatial data, tools, and models for fire and natural resource management, planning, and implementation
Identifying and comparing management priorities, evaluating threats to ecosystems, and exploring outcomes under alternative management scenarios

title: About this Project
text:
LANDFIRE’s Mission
LANDFIRE’s mission is to provide agency leaders and managers with a common “all-lands” data set of vegetation and wildland fire/fuels information for strategic fire and resource management planning and analysis.

title: About this Project
text:
Biophysical Settings Products

Quick intro
A Biophysical Setting (BpS) is a concept that represents the vegetation that may have been dominant on the landscape prior to European colonization of North America and is based on both the current biophysical environment and an approximation of the historical disturbance regime.
LANDFIRE collaborated with experts around the country to create a description and model for every BpS it mapped across the US.
Check out the vegetation modeling website to learn how to integrate BpS into your work.


Resources

Vegetation dynamics models: a comprehensive set for natural resource assessment and planning in the United States. Kori Blankenship, Randy Swaty, Kimberly R. Hall, Sarah Hagen, Kelly Pohl, Ayn Shlisky Hunt, Jeannie Patton, Leonardo Frid, Jim Smith
BpS Descriptions and Models information
Information about the BpS Spatial Data

Vegetation Products

Quick Intro
LANDFIRE existing vegetation layers describe the following elements: Existing Vegetation Type, Existing Vegetation Canopy Cover, and Existing Vegetation Height (EVH). These layers are created using predictive landscape models based on extensive field-referenced data, satellite imagery and biophysical gradient layers using classification and regression trees.’ (from https://landfire.gov/vegetation.php)

title: Present: Current Ecosystem Conditions
text: The following LANDFIRE vegetation products are based on LF 2022 data release.

title: Present: Current Ecosystem Conditions
text:
Summary
In general, the Ouachita National Forest, as of 2022, has experienced some interesting shifts. Care should be taken when directly comparing past and present maps, as classification systems for Biophysical Settings do not always align with the most current NatureServe (2016) ecosystem descriptions. With this caveat in mind, some patterns are worth noting:

Shortleaf pine and oak dominated systems are still the most prevalent vegetation types on the forest, though much of the vegetation types have shifted from “woodland” descriptions to more “forest” descriptions, indicating an increase in canopy cover.
The most prevalent past Biophysical Setting, Ozark-Ouachita Shortleaf Pine-Oak Forest and Woodland is no longer the most prevalent vegetation type. Large areas of in the central and southeastern portion of the forest appear to have been converted to pasture and plantation, presumably due to the low gradient associated with this community.
The southwestern portion of the forest represents the most development, with the majority of the area now converted from West Gulf Coastal Plain Pine-Hardwood Forest and Gulf and Atlantic Coastal Plain Floodplain Systems to pasture and plantation.
The Ouachita National Forest remains heavily forested, as indicated by the EVC and EVH.
